questions.text: Identify the following intracytoplasmic inclusion isolated from brain biopsy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Negri bodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Negri bodies are diagnostic of rabies and are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies found in neurons, particularly in the hippocampus and cerebellum .
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Types of Inclusion Bodies
  • ➤ Types of Inclusion Bodies
  • ➤ Inclusion bodies can be categorized based on their location within the host cell, as mentioned in the transcript:
  • ➤ 1. Intracytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies:
  • ➤ 1. Intracytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies:
  • ➤ Found in the cytoplasm of host cells. Examples: Negri bodies (Rabies virus) Guarnieri bodies (Vaccinia virus) Paschen bodies (Variola virus) Bollinger bodies (Fowlpox virus) Henderson-Peterson bodies (Molluscum contagiosum)
  • ➤ Found in the cytoplasm of host cells.
  • ➤ Examples: Negri bodies (Rabies virus) Guarnieri bodies (Vaccinia virus) Paschen bodies (Variola virus) Bollinger bodies (Fowlpox virus) Henderson-Peterson bodies (Molluscum contagiosum)
  • ➤ Negri bodies (Rabies virus) Guarnieri bodies (Vaccinia virus) Paschen bodies (Variola virus) Bollinger bodies (Fowlpox virus) Henderson-Peterson bodies (Molluscum contagiosum)
  • ➤ Negri bodies (Rabies virus)
  • ➤ Negri bodies
  • ➤ Guarnieri bodies (Vaccinia virus)
  • ➤ Guarnieri bodies
  • ➤ Paschen bodies (Variola virus)
  • ➤ Paschen bodies
  • ➤ Bollinger bodies (Fowlpox virus)
  • ➤ Bollinger bodies
  • ➤ Henderson-Peterson bodies (Molluscum contagiosum)
  • ➤ Henderson-Peterson bodies
  • ➤ 2. Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies:
  • ➤ 2. Intranuclear Inclusion Bodies:
  • ➤ Found in the nucleus of host cells. Two types: Cowdry Type A: Granular appearance (e.g., Herpesvirus, Varicella-Zoster virus, Yellow fever virus).
  • ➤ Found in the nucleus of host cells.
  • ➤ Two types: Cowdry Type A: Granular appearance (e.g., Herpesvirus, Varicella-Zoster virus, Yellow fever virus).
  • ➤ Cowdry Type A: Granular appearance (e.g., Herpesvirus, Varicella-Zoster virus, Yellow fever virus).
  • ➤ Cowdry Type A: Granular appearance (e.g., Herpesvirus, Varicella-Zoster virus, Yellow fever virus).
  • ➤ Cowdry Type A:
  • ➤ Cowdry Type B: Compact, circumscribed appearance (e.g., Polio, Adenovirus).
  • ➤ Cowdry Type B: Compact, circumscribed appearance (e.g., Polio, Adenovirus).
  • ➤ Cowdry Type B:
  • ➤ 3. Inclusions in Both Cytoplasm and Nucleus:
  • ➤ 3. Inclusions in Both Cytoplasm and Nucleus:
  • ➤ Found in both the cytoplasm and nucleus of host cells. Examples: Measles virus (Warthin-Finkeldey bodies) Cytomegalovirus (Owl-eye appearance)
  • ➤ Found in both the cytoplasm and nucleus of host cells.
  • ➤ Examples: Measles virus (Warthin-Finkeldey bodies) Cytomegalovirus (Owl-eye appearance)
  • ➤ Measles virus (Warthin-Finkeldey bodies) Cytomegalovirus (Owl-eye appearance)
  • ➤ Measles virus (Warthin-Finkeldey bodies)
  • ➤ Measles virus
  • ➤ Cytomegalovirus (Owl-eye appearance)
  • ➤ Cytomegalovirus

questions.text: A child presented with umbilicated pearly lesions in the face following this; mother also had developed the same lesion. Identify the virus causing a lesion?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pox virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Umbilicated pearly lesions, particularly in children and close contacts, are diagnostic of molluscum contagiosum, caused by a member of the poxvirus family.

questions.text: Guarnieri inclusion body is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vaccinia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Guarnieri inclusion bodies are diagnostic of vaccinia virus infection and were historically significant in the development of the smallpox vaccine.

questions.text: All are about polio, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 90%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Paralytic polio occurs in less than 1% of cases, with the majority being nonparalytic or asymptomatic. Paralytic polio is characterized by asymmetric flaccid paralysis without sensory loss.

questions.text: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is caused by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) JC virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a demyelinating disease caused by the JC virus, a Polyomavirus that primarily affects immunocompromised individuals, including AIDS and transplant patients.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man has undergone lung transplantation. Two months after transplantation, he developed pulmonary symptoms and diagnosed as having bilateral diffuse interstitial pulmonary pneumonitis and bronchiolitis. Which of the following etiological agent is responsible in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cytomegalovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cytomegalovirus is the most common viral cause of interstitial pneumonia in transplant recipients, typically occurring 1 to 4 months post-transplant and characterized by owl-eye inclusion bodies on histology.

questions.text: Space vehicle virus is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Adenovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adenovirus, a double-stranded DNA virus with a capsid composed of 252 capsomers, is called the "space vehicle virus" due to its unique structure.

questions.text: Lysogenic conversion is:

options.label: A
options.text: New properties in a bacterium due to integration of phage genome

options.label: B
options.text: Transfer of DNA from one bacterium to another by bacteriophage

options.label: D
options.text: Transfer of genome during physical contact

questions.correct_answer: A. New properties in a bacterium due to integration of phage genome
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) New properties in a bacterium due to integration of phage genome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lysogenic conversion refers to the acquisition of new properties by a bacterium due to the integration of a bacteriophage's genome into its own DNA, often enhancing bacterial virulence or survival.

questions.text: Nonenveloped SS-RNA virus is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Picornavirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Picornavirus is a small, non-enveloped (naked), single-stranded RNA virus, making it the correct answer. Mnemonics such as "PCR" (Picornavirus, Calicivirus, Reovirus) help to remember the non-enveloped RNA viruses.

questions.text: The virus with smallest genome is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Parvovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The smallest viral genome overall is Parvovirus (5 kb, single-stranded DNA). Learn the key distinctions between the smallest and largest genomes in virology for both DNA and RNA viruses.

questions.text: Von-magnus phenomenon is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Von-Magnus phenomenon is observed in influenza virus and is characterized by abnormal viral replication, leading to progeny with low infectivity and high hemagglutination activity. All options listed in the question are correct.

questions.text: Both intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Measles virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles virus is characterized by the presence of both intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusion bodies (Warthin-Finkeldey bodies), making it unique among the options provided.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presented with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea of one week duration. The following colonic biopsy is diagnostic of infection with:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Amoebiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of flask-shaped ulcers in a colonic biopsy is diagnostic of Amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. The infective form is the quadrinucleated cyst, and the invasive form is the trophozoite.
  • ➤ Amoebiasis

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl residing in a village recently returned from a vacation visiting her friends in another village. She complained of severe headache and fever, was diagnosed as a case of pyogenic meningitis and admitted to the hospital. She died 5 days later. Which of the following organism should be considered in the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Naegleria fowleri

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Naegleria fowleri is a neuroparasite causing primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM), which is rapidly fatal and often associated with swimming in contaminated freshwater. It should be suspected in cases of acute meningitis with a history of freshwater exposure.

questions.text: Host harboring adult or sexual stage of a parasite is called:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Definitive host

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A definitive host is the host in which the adult or sexual stage of a parasite is found. This definition applies to both protozoan and metazoan parasites. For the intermediate host, it’s the asexual or larval stages that are present.
  • ➤ definitive host

questions.text: The cystic form of all are seen in man except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trichomonas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The only protozoan parasite in the given options that lacks a cystic form and exists solely as a trophozoite is Trichomonas vaginalis .
  • ➤ Trichomonas vaginalis

questions.text: Vector for T. cruzi is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reduviid bug

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vector for Trypanosoma cruzi is the Reduviid bug, and transmission occurs through contact with feces containing the infective trypomastigote, not via saliva. This unique transmission mechanism is a key feature of Chagas disease.

questions.text: How many pairs of flagella does Giardia lamblia possess?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Four

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giardia lamblia possesses four pairs of flagella (eight in total), and its characteristic motility is described as "falling leaf" motion. This key fact is essential for identifying the organism.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with acute watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps. Stool microscopy reveals trophozoites with falling leaf motility. The etiological agent is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Giardia lamblia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of trophozoites with falling leaf motility in stool microscopy strongly indicates Giardia lamblia as the etiological agent, which causes watery diarrhea and malabsorption syndrome.

questions.text: Ziemann’s stippling of erythrocyte is caused by which species of plasmodium?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Malariae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ziemann’s stippling is a hallmark feature of Plasmodium malariae. Learn the differences in stippling patterns to accurately identify the species causing malaria.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of dysphagia. On UGI Endoscopy a diagnosis of esophageal candidiasis was made. The organism obtained from the sample was cultured on a specialized media and the below finding were visible on microscopy of the culture. What phenomenon is shown below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Germ tube formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The germ tube test is specific for Candida albicans and helps differentiate it from other Candida species, showing filamentous germ tube structures after incubation in serum.

questions.text: The image given below belongs which of the following organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cryptococcus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cryptococcus is a capsulated fungus identified by its thick capsule visible in India ink preparation, which appears as a clear halo around the yeast cells.

questions.text: Which of the organisms is responsible for orbital cellulitis in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mucor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucormycosis is the most common fungal cause of orbital cellulitis in diabetic or immunosuppressed patients, especially in the presence of diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: Biochemical analysis of pyogenic meningitis reveals all of the following, except:

options.label: B
options.text: Total leukocyte count: Highly elevated, neutrophilic

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucose: highly elevated

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In pyogenic meningitis, glucose levels in the CSF are decreased, not elevated, due to bacterial consumption of glucose as a nutrient.

questions.text: MCC of catheter induced UTI:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) E. coli

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ E. coli is the most common cause of UTIs, including catheter-induced UTIs, due to its ability to adhere to the urinary tract and form biofilms.

questions.text: A Female had a thorn prick 5 years ago. She presented with a slowly growing 2 × 2 cm verrucous lesion which on KOH mount showed the following image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chromoblastomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by verrucous lesions and the presence of copper pennies (Medlar bodies) on KOH mount, often following traumatic implantation such as a thorn prick.

questions.text: Rhinosporidium seeberi belongs to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aquatic protistan protozoa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidium seeberi is an aquatic protistan protozoa that causes nasal polyps and is characterized by spherules with endospores on microscopic examination.

questions.text: Cigar body is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Sporotrichosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cigar bodies (asteroid bodies) are a hallmark feature of sporotrichosis, a fungal infection commonly seen in individuals exposed to thorn pricks or handling vegetation.

questions.text: Darling disease is caused by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Histoplasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Darling disease is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum and primarily affects the lungs, with potential for dissemination in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: Histopathological image given below belongs to which of the following fungus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Blastomyces

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "figure of eight" appearance with a thick double wall in histopathological images is diagnostic of blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis.
  • ➤ blastomycosis

questions.text: Thirty-eight children consumed eatables procured from a single source at a picnic party. Twenty children developed abdominal cramps followed by vomiting and watery diarrhea 6–10 hours after the party. The most likely etiology for the outbreak is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Clostridium perfringens infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Food poisoning caused by Clostridium perfringens typically presents with symptoms after an incubation period of 8–16 hours, including abdominal cramps, vomiting, and watery diarrhea.

questions.text: EBV action in nasopharynx is through:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) CD 21

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) enters B lymphocytes and epithelial cells through the CD21 receptor, leading to both benign (infectious mononucleosis) and malignant conditions (e.g., Burkitt lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma).

questions.text: Paul Bunnell test for:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Infectious mononucleosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Paul Bunnell test detects heterophile antibodies in the serum and is a diagnostic test for infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).

questions.text: Segmented genome is found in all, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rhabdovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Among RNA viruses, the four with segmented genomes are remembered by the mnemonic "BORA" (Bunyavirus, Orthomyxovirus, Reovirus, Arenavirus). Rhabdovirus is non-segmented and does not belong to this group.

questions.text: Slapped cheek appearance with fever is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B19

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Slapped cheek appearance in children is pathognomonic of erythema infectiosum, caused by Parvovirus B19, the smallest DNA virus and the only single-stranded DNA virus.

questions.text: Eggs of which of the following parasite cause intense pruritus in perianal skin:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Enterobius vermicularis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The eggs of Enterobius vermicularis cause intense perianal pruritus, especially at night, due to the female worm's egg-laying behavior. This leads to auto-infection and a continuous cycle in the host.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is implicated in the causation of botryomycosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Staphylococcus aureus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Botryomycosis is a bacterial infection caused primarily by Staphylococcus aureus and is often misinterpreted as a fungal infection due to its name and clinical presentation.
  • ➤ Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: Consumption of uncooked beef is likely to cause which of the following helminthic diseases:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Taenia saginata

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Consumption of uncooked beef causes Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm) infection. The infective form is the Cysticercus bovis, found in the muscles of cattle.

questions.text: Following type of eggs are seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Schistosoma mansoni

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of a lateral spine on the egg is diagnostic of Schistosoma mansoni. Differentiate Schistosoma species by their egg morphology: Terminal spine: Schistosoma haematobium Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni Knob: Schistosoma japonicum.
  • ➤ The presence of a lateral spine on the egg is diagnostic of Schistosoma mansoni.
  • ➤ lateral spine
  • ➤ Differentiate Schistosoma species by their egg morphology: Terminal spine: Schistosoma haematobium Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni Knob: Schistosoma japonicum.
  • ➤ Terminal spine: Schistosoma haematobium Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni Knob: Schistosoma japonicum.
  • ➤ Terminal spine: Schistosoma haematobium
  • ➤ Terminal spine:
  • ➤ Lateral spine: Schistosoma mansoni
  • ➤ Lateral spine:
  • ➤ Knob: Schistosoma japonicum.
  • ➤ Knob:

questions.text: Identify the organism from its egg in the picture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Necator americanus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The egg with four blastomeres and a non-bile-stained appearance is diagnostic of Necator americanus , a hookworm species that causes iron-deficiency anemia through chronic blood loss in infected individuals.
  • ➤ Necator americanus

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presented to the OPD with pain in the anogenital region. On examination, multiple warts were seen. A suspicion of HPV infection, a genetic analysis was done which showed that she is at high risk of invasive CA cervix. Which of the following type of HPV is responsible for this?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) HPV 18

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HPV16 and HPV18 are high-risk types associated with cervical cancer, while HPV6 and HPV11 are low-risk types that cause benign warts. In this case, the high-risk HPV type responsible is HPV18.

questions.text: Winter bottom sign in sleeping sickness refers to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Winterbottom sign refers to posterior cervical lymphadenopathy , which is a classic feature of early-stage African trypanosomiasis caused by Trypanosoma brucei and transmitted by the tsetse fly (Glossina) .
  • ➤ Winterbottom sign
  • ➤ posterior cervical lymphadenopathy
  • ➤ tsetse fly (Glossina)

questions.text: Which among the following exist in yeast form at 37°C and hyphal form at 25°C?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Histoplasma capsulatum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dimorphic fungi, such as Histoplasma capsulatum, exist as yeast at 37°C and mould at 25°C.

questions.text: Infective form to mosquito in plasmodium falciparum:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gametocytes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The infective form of Plasmodium falciparum for mosquitoes is the gametocyte , while the infective form for humans is the sporozoite . Importantly, the mosquito (female Anopheles) is the definitive host as sexual reproduction of the parasite occurs in the mosquito.
  • ➤ gametocyte
  • ➤ sporozoite

questions.text: Identify the vector that is involved in following diagnostic image:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ixodid tick

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The vector for Babesia is the Ixodid tick , specifically species from the Ixodes genus. The hallmark diagnostic feature is the presence of the Maltese cross within RBCs, visible under microscopy.
  • ➤ Ixodid tick
  • ➤ Maltese cross

questions.text: True about diphyllobothrium:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Operculated egg is diagnostic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnostic feature of Diphyllobothrium latum infection is its operculated eggs, found in the feces of infected individuals. This parasite causes megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency.

questions.text: Adult worm of Echinococcus is found in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dog

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The adult worm of Echinococcus is found exclusively in carnivorous definitive hosts, such as dogs, wolves, and foxes. Humans are accidental hosts, and intermediate hosts include herbivorous animals like sheep and cattle.

questions.text: Rash of chicken pox is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Centripetal distribution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chickenpox rash has a centripetal distribution (CP for CP), is pleomorphic, superficial, and resolves within 7 days, sparing palms and soles.

questions.text: 40-year-old male from Bihar complains of abdomen pain, having hepatosplenomegaly, smear on stain shows?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leishmania

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of LD bodies (macrophages containing amastigote forms) in a smear is diagnostic of Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis) . This disease is transmitted by the bite of the sandfly, Phlebotomus argentipes, and is endemic in regions like Bihar and Jharkhand.
  • ➤ Kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis)

questions.text: This is a schematic diagram depicting body structure of which of these helminthes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Wuchereria bancrofti

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wuchereria bancrofti is identified by the presence of a sheath and the absence of nuclei at the tip of the tail.
